@ 26:05 I think that answer is kind of confusing. Here's my understanding. Yes, the light and the tube would be stretched equally thus no way of detecting it if the tube was one directional, this is why there are two arms at 90 degrees to one another. As he said, if the gravity waves were coming from zenith, directly above or below, it would be null, meaning impossible to detect because both tubes and both sides of the lasers would be affected equally. To detect "vertical" gravity waves, relative to Ligo, we would need a third arm 90 degree vertical, a Z axis. This is 2d detector only x,y axis, thus only gravity waves traveling in a 2d plane relative to the detector can be detected.

I don't know which way those arms are oriented but lets say one is North-South and the other East-West. So if a gravity wave comes from the south it would ONLY affect the N-S arm as it travels through the detector. By itself the N-S arm would never notice the stretching since both the arm and the laser are stretched, BUT...
...because there is also an E-W arm, and because there is only ONE laser beam, split in two at the junction, then sent in both directions at the same time and same frequency, after a N-S gravity wave the N-S arm laser would return to the detector with a slightly altered frequency(most likely due to time dilatation), while the E-W laser would have the same standard frequency it left with. Because both lasers started as one, they should always be the same frequency on return. It's the difference in frequency between the two arms, on the same split laser, that's the hint that Gravity Waves may be happening. But not absolute proof yet...
If it's a truck or an earth quake both would be disturbed the same, or in almost identically, only gravity waves coming from the South direction would cause the N-S half of the laser beam to alter it's frequency while not interfering with the E-W.

Now to prove for sure it's gravity waves the source has to be identified. Telescopes are used to look directly South relative to Ligo to so see what could have caused the gravity waves. If a potential culprit is found that's confirmation that indeed a gravity wave was detected.

This is my understanding. If I'm wrong feel free to correct me.

I'm used to seeing Unix timestamps, so the GPS time on the clock confused me. They're in Washington State, so it makes sense that the first clock is UTC and the second one is PDT (UTC -7). Normally when you see time as seconds, it's a Unix timestamp (which is time since Jan 1, 1970), but 1,247,942,086 is too small of a number when I tried that in Python...

>>> import datetime
>>> datetime.datetime.utcfromtimestamp(1247942086).isoformat()
'2009-07-18T18:34:46'

International Atomic Time (TAI) = time since Jan 6, 1980 ... so let's try that ...

>>> (datetime.datetime(1980, 1, 6) + datetime.timedelta(seconds=1247942086)).isoformat()
'2019-07-23T18:34:46'

But their first clock says 18:34:28 ... so we're off by 18 seconds. And ... as of Dec 31, 2016 there have been 18 leap seconds since 1980. GPS Time is the time since Jan 6, 1980 without the added leap seconds (although it's normally in a weird format with a 10-bit week number and a 20-bit number for seconds in the week)...

>>> (datetime.datetime(1980, 1, 6) + datetime.timedelta(seconds=(1247942086 - 18))).isoformat()
'2019-07-23T18:34:28'

>>> (datetime.datetime(1980, 1, 6).replace(tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc) + datetime.timedelta(seconds=(1247942086 - 18))).astimezone(datetime.timezone(datetime.timedelta(hours=-7))).isoformat()
'2019-07-23T11:34:28-07:00'

So I guess that makes sense. And it looks like this video was recorded July 23 at 11:30 am PDT.

Diana - Not a critique, just a comment: You didn't touch on the key to how LIGO works: At each LIGO observatory, there are TWO laser systems oriented 90° to each other, and any sufficiently strong gravitational waves do indeed 'stretch' the frequency of the light from both of those two different lasers. This means that, unless the source of the incoming gravity waves is at a PRECISE angle to the detector complex (exactly at 45° - picture an isosceles triangle bisected by a point from the exact middle of the hypotenuse to the node of the opposite angle), then the gravitational waves will stretch each 90° leg differently - and this means that subsequently combining the signals from BOTH laser legs will then yield a 'waving' interference pattern in intensity that can be analyzed to glean MUCH information about that particular event.


I understand and appreciate that you're a popular EXPERT at presenting physics to a likely unexposed audience, and I am ever so grateful that you do so, so I get that your omission here was most likely deliberate.


Again - this comment is intended as a clarification, not a critique, and I think it's AWESOME both that you do what you do, AND how you do it!

We can use gravitational waves for permanently warping any object. Gravitational waves stretch space in one ☝️ dimension and shrink in the other. Webber (https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Weber), the father of experimental gravitational wave research, taught a class I was in in grad school.
